content:
**New Zealand Navy Ship Runs Aground Off the Coast of Samoa**

A New Zealand Navy ship ran aground on Saturday evening while conducting an aquatic terrain survey near the shore of Samoa. The vessel encountered shallow waters and subsequently caught fire. By 6:40 a.m. local time (1940 UTC) on Sunday, plumes of smoke were observed rising from the ship. By 9 a.m. local time (2200 UTC) Sunday, the vessel was reported fully submerged, according to an official update from the New Zealand Navy.

The evacuation of the crew began at 7:52 p.m. local time (0852 UTC on October 7), and all personnel were successfully rescued and brought ashore. The operation was carried out with support from the Rescue Coordination Centre New Zealand (RCCNZ) and the Royal New Zealand Air Force. Additionally, the Air Force deployed resources to Samoa on Sunday evening to provide on-site medical and welfare assistance, as well as to help with the cleanup efforts.

Seventy-two of the rescued crew members are scheduled to return to Auckland on Monday evening, while three remaining personnel will fly back to New Zealand on a commercial flight on Tuesday.

title: Rio Negro tributary of the Amazon River experiences lowest water level on record
content:
On Friday, Brazil's Geological Service, a government agency, reported that water levels in the Rio Negro have dropped to 12.66 meters, marking the lowest recorded level since data collection began in 1902. The drop in water levels has been attributed to severe wildfires and prolonged drought conditions. 

Authorities indicated that this has been the harshest drought in over 120 years. As a result, residents are facing job losses, longer journeys to access drinking water, and difficulties for boats navigating the now shallow river.

The Rio Negro is recognized as the largest blackwater river in the world.

title: General secretary of Social Democratic Party of Germany resigns due to health problems ahead of next year elections
content:
This past Monday, Kühnert announced his resignation as general secretary of the Social Democratic Party (SPD) ahead of a national election next year, citing health concerns. He informed the party leadership of his decision and shared a farewell message with party members on his social media platform.

At 35 years old, Kühnert did not provide additional details regarding his health.

The SPD has been the ruling party since the 2021 elections, when it elected its leader as Chancellor, akin to the role of Prime Minister in other countries. However, the party lagged behind its rivals in the earlier election this year.

title: Thailand's Ping River water levels reach record high in 50 years
content:
Floodwaters in Chiang Mai, Thailand's largest city, reached a record high of 5.3 meters over the weekend, the highest level in 50 years. By 10 AM on Monday, water levels had decreased to 3.85 meters and were continuing to decline. Authorities took measurements at various locations throughout the city.

As of Monday, health officials reported that 80 residents had evacuated, and at least three fatalities were confirmed due to the flooding.

In response to the rising waters, some shops closed, and train services in the neighboring areas were suspended. Residents faced the challenge of navigating through approximately one meter of water, with some relying on trucks for evacuation. Authorities also closed several major roads and advised residents downstream to evacuate or prepare for potential flooding.

The heavy rainfall reportedly began in early September, contributing to the current situation.

Chiang Mai is a prominent city in northern Thailand and a popular tourist destination.

title: Azov Brigade to be allowed to use US weapons
content:
On Monday, the United States lifted a decade-old restriction on the use of weapons by the Azov Brigade in Ukraine, concluding that the group has not committed any gross human rights violations. The Azov Brigade gained prominence for its role in the conflict during Russia's invasion in 2022. While the group has been labeled by Russia as a far-right, ultranationalist, extremist, racist, and neo-Nazi organization, it is officially recognized as the 12th Special Forces Brigade in Ukraine.

The prior ban on the Azov Brigade's access to American weapons stemmed from concerns regarding the extremist ideologies associated with its founders. Human Rights Watch had also raised issues related to human rights violations involving brigade members. According to the brigade's official website, since 2014, it has been engaged in a process of "cleansing" itself of undesirable elements. The US State Department, however, stated that there was "no evidence of gross violations of human rights" attributed to the brigade.

Notably, Russia has designated the Azov Brigade as a terrorist organization since 2022. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov criticized the brigade, calling it an "ultranationalist armed formation" and accused the US of "flirting with neo-Nazis," suggesting that Washington is using the "Ukrainian people as an instrument."

In response to the US decision, the Azov Brigade characterized the move as a "new page" in its history, asserting that they are "becoming even more powerful, more professional, and more dangerous for occupiers." The brigade also announced that this development would enhance its combat capabilities and contribute to the safety and health of its personnel.

Previously, the Azov Brigade had been restricted from participating in US-led military exercises and receiving American weapons. Formed in 2014 to combat Russian separatists, the brigade was integrated into the Ukrainian National Guard in 2015.

title: Data breach and DDOS attacks bring down Wayback Machine
content:
On Wednesday, the Internet Archive experienced a significant data breach, compromising the passwords and screen names of 31 million users. Concurrently, the Archive faced a series of distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, which rendered the site temporarily inaccessible. While it remains uncertain if the two incidents are linked, current evidence suggests they may have been executed by the same individual or group.

Just before the shutdown, users attempting to access the Internet Archive were met with a JavaScript pop-up message stating: "Have you ever felt like the Internet Archive runs on sticks and is constantly on the verge of suffering a catastrophic security breach? It just happened. See 31 million of you on HIBP!" Here, "HIBP" refers to "Have I Been Pwned," a service that allows users to check if their credentials have been compromised in a data breach.

As of Saturday, both the Internet Archive and its popular Wayback Machine tool remained unavailable to the public while staff worked diligently to enhance server security and prevent future incidents. Since its founding in 1996, the Archive has been committed to providing "universal access to all knowledge."

The Wayback Machine allows users to view historical snapshots of websites, but access to this resource is expected to be restored within the coming days, though no specific timeline has been announced.

A hacker group operating under the name SN_Blackmeta on X (formerly Twitter) has claimed responsibility for the attacks and is believed to be based in Russia. The group has expressed political motivations, accusing the U.S. government of supporting Israel, which they cite as their reason for targeting the Internet Archive.

The breach likely occurred on September 28, as indicated by the most recent date on a 6.4 gigabyte SQL file containing the stolen user data. HIBP founder Troy Hunt received the file on September 30, but he was unable to investigate its contents until October 5. He subsequently alerted the Internet Archive staff on October 6, who have since taken steps to mitigate the impact of the DDoS attacks and enhance their security measures.

title: Former leader of the Scottish National Party Alex Salmond dies at 69
content:
**Former SNP Leader Alex Salmond Dies After Heart Attack in North Macedonia**

Alex Salmond, the former leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), passed away on Saturday, October 12, 2024, after suffering a heart attack while attending an international conference in North Macedonia. Shortly after delivering a speech, Salmond collapsed during lunch. A report was filed to the Ohrid police station at approximately 3:30 PM, and emergency medical personnel arrived, but he was pronounced dead at the scene.

Salmond was a prominent advocate for Scottish independence and served as Scotland's first minister, becoming the earliest leader to champion the cause.

Following the news of his passing, notable political figures, including Keir Starmer (the current Prime Minister of the UK and leader of the Labour Party), Rishi Sunak (the previous Prime Minister and leader of the Conservative Party), and Scotland's Secretary of State, offered their condolences. Starmer expressed that Salmond "cared deeply about Scotland and the communities he represented."

title: Massachusetts Institute of Technology engineers tap access to battery-less desalination of more groundwater than ever before
content:
This past Tuesday, researchers unveiled a groundbreaking method for water desalination that eliminates the need for large on-site batteries or direct connections to the power grid. Engineers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) published their findings on a new and cost-effective battery-less solar desalination technology in the esteemed journal, *Water*.

The innovative system is designed to adapt desalination rates multiple times per second in response to fluctuations in solar irradiance, effectively managing changes in electric current brought on by varying weather conditions.

Researchers conducted tests on a prototype at the Brackish Groundwater National Desalination Research Facility in New Mexico for several months, demonstrating its capability to desalinate an average of 5,000 liters of water per day.

This system specifically targets brackish groundwater, which is more abundant yet has remained largely untapped due to previous technological constraints. This advancement holds particular promise for drought-stricken inland areas that lack easy access to seawater, making it a valuable resource for those regions.

title: TV host Willie Revillame files certificate of candidacy for upcoming Philippine elections
content:
Filipino TV host Willie Revillame has officially submitted his Certificate of Candidacy (COC) to the Commission on Elections (COMELEC) on October 8, announcing his intention to run for senator in the upcoming 2025 midterm elections. Revillame is well-known for hosting popular variety shows such as "Wowowin," among others.

At a prayer rally held in Davao City on January 28, Willie first revealed his plans to enter the senatorial race. He disclosed that he had previously received an invitation to join the senatorial slate of former President Rodrigo Duterte and Senator Bong Go. However, he decided to decline the offer at that time due to existing contractual commitments with his show.

In the lead-up to his candidacy, there was growing speculation regarding the possible relocation of Revillame's show to PTV 4. This speculation was fueled by the circulation of images showing his visit to the network's facilities in Quezon City, alongside the Presidential Communications Operations Office, on social media.

title: Bruce Lehrmann judge said to have no links to published book of judgement
content:
On October 15, 2024, a spokesperson confirmed that neither the court nor Justice Michael Lee, who presided over the defamation trial that concluded in April, was involved in the publication of a book related to Lee’s judgment. This clarification came after Melbourne University Publishing (MUP) announced its plans to release a book titled *He Went Back for His Hat*, with Justice Lee credited as the author on the publisher's website.

In response to the court’s remarks, Professor Emeritus Warren Bebbington, chairman of the MUP board, informed *The Sydney Morning Herald* that they had consulted Justice Lee before making the announcement and that he had no objections to the book’s publication. "The book was an initiative of MUP, but Justice Lee was approached by us in advance and did not see any issue with the publication of a judgment that is in the public domain," Bebbington stated. He further noted that MUP did not seek Justice Lee's approval for the book's title or cover.

The title of the book alludes to a remark made by Justice Lee regarding former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann’s choice to sue Network 10 after criminal charges against him were dropped. "Having escaped the lion's den, Mr. Lehrmann made the mistake of going back for his hat," Lee commented. The case involved Lehrmann's defamation lawsuit against Network 10 and Brittany Higgins following an interview she gave. Ultimately, Judge Lee found that on the balance of probabilities, Lehrmann had raped Higgins. Lehrmann previously faced criminal charges for the alleged assault, which were dismissed due to juror misconduct.

In May 2024, Lehrmann filed an appeal against the court’s decision in the defamation case. In June, Network 10 requested the court to require him to pay AUD 200,000 in security to cover some of their legal costs related to the appeal. Lehrmann's solicitor, Zali Burrows, opposed this request, arguing that Lehrmann was on Centrelink benefits and unable to make the payment. "The only shot he'd probably ever have in making money is by going on [television] or something silly like that," Burrows told the court.

title: Thousands of pagers explode in Lebanon killing twelve people and injuring thousands
content:
On Tuesday, a series of coordinated explosions rocked southern Beirut, Lebanon, resulting in the tragic deaths of twelve individuals and injuring approximately 2,800 others. CNN reported that the blasts primarily targeted Hezbollah, a Lebanese political party and paramilitary organization. The exact cause of the explosions remains under investigation, but preliminary findings have pointed to the possibility that the devices were either rigged with explosives or had faulty batteries, according to Reuters. 

The following day, additional explosions from walkie-talkies, laptops, and radios led to an increased death toll, with 20 more fatalities and 450 additional injuries reported. 

Experts from the consulting firm Predicta Lab indicated to CNN that hardware tampering was likely a factor in the pager explosions, dismissing the possibility of a cyberattack. They suggested that the malicious modifications could have occurred before the bulk shipment arrived in the country.

Reports indicated that a shipment of the targeted pagers had been sitting at a port for three months, awaiting completion of import paperwork. Investigators have suggested that the pagers contained one to three grams of an explosive substance alongside metal balls, seemingly added to amplify the explosion's impact.

The timing of the attack appears to coincide with Hezbollah's investigation into reports of inconsistent battery life among the batch of pagers, as noted by sources.

The pagers in question are produced by a Taiwanese company. On Wednesday, Gold Apollo, the affiliated company, stated that the devices were manufactured by BAC Consulting KFT, a firm based in Hungary's capital. However, Hungarian authorities have since denied any involvement by BAC Consulting KFT in the manufacturing process. The CEO of BAC Consulting KFT told NBC News that the company acted as an "intermediate" but did not manufacture the pagers. The BBC has reported that official records show BAC registered at an address associated with multiple organizations, none of which operates as a manufacturing facility.

A law professor from Indiana University condemned the attacks, emphasizing the prohibition against weaponizing devices used by civilians. The United Nations has also called for a thorough investigation into the matter.

Lebanon's government described the incident as an "Israeli cyberattack," although Israel has not claimed responsibility. These explosions occur against a backdrop of heightened tensions between Israel and Hezbollah, which have escalated since the onset of conflict in 2023.

title: On the campaign trail in the USA, May 2024
content:
**Election Update: Monthly Recap of the 2024 U.S. Presidential Race**

This marks the inaugural edition of our monthly series covering the 2024 United States presidential election. Inside, you'll find original content compiled over the past month, alongside an overview of major polling trends and the most significant stories in the race.

**Campaign Trail Highlights**

This month's feature delves into an exclusive behind-the-scenes look at the U.S. Reform Party's process for selecting its presidential nominee, the ongoing turmoil at the Trump trial, and an interview with the Libertarian Party's recently appointed vice presidential nominee.

As of early May, former President Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, led President Joe Biden, the presumed Democratic nominee, in head-to-head polling 46.6% to 45.1%. When independent candidates—specifically presumptive Green Party nominee Jill Stein and Robert F. Kennedy Jr.—were included, Trump's lead expanded to 41.4%, compared to 39.2% for Biden, 10.2% for Kennedy, 2.1% for Cornel West, and 1.6% for Stein.

By the end of May, Trump continued to lead Biden, 45.4% to 44.6% in the head-to-head matchup, and 41.9% to 39.7% in a five-way race that included Kennedy, Stein, and West.

Trump's legal troubles continued to unfold in New York, where testimony from adult film star Stormy Daniels and his former attorney was heard. A judicial order restricted Trump's comments about the trial, but he still managed to criticize Judge Juan Merchan and prosecutor Alvin Bragg, alleging that Biden and the White House orchestrated the case against him. Ultimately, Trump was found guilty of all 34 felony counts. In the aftermath, his campaign reportedly raised over $50 million within 24 hours.

Amid these legal challenges, Trump maintained a campaign schedule in New York City, including rallies in New Jersey and the Bronx, even stopping at a bodega in Harlem. He asserted that traditionally Democratic states like New York and New Jersey could be viable targets for his campaign this November.

While stopping short of outright endorsement, former Trump rival Nikki Haley indicated she would vote for Trump in November, despite continuing to secure a notable percentage of support in her own campaign. Trump has denied any interest in selecting Haley as his running mate. Among potential vice presidential picks for Trump, media speculation includes Senators Tim Scott, Kevin Cramer, and Marco Rubio, as well as Congresswoman Elise Stefanik and former Governor Larry Hogan.

In a twist, an Ohio ballot access law cast doubt on Biden's ability to qualify for the state ballot, as his official nomination was set for the Democratic National Convention in August. To circumvent this issue, the Democratic Party opted for a June ceremony to officially nominate Biden. Meanwhile, Ohio lawmakers passed an amendment to ensure Biden's presence on the ballot.

Biden has agreed to two debates with Trump, the first taking place on June 27—an unprecedented early date for the general election debates. Vice President Kamala Harris is set to debate Trump's yet-to-be-selected running mate.

The Biden campaign has also targeted Trump over a controversial ad that features the phrase "Unified America." By extension, Biden emphasized Trump's alleged comments regarding his programming choices on the reality show "The Apprentice" in 2004, highlighted by an expose from producer Bill Pruitt.

In other news, Biden addressed graduates at a college in Delaware, condemning what he called the "poison of extremism." Despite the institution not facing widespread protests, some graduates protested by turning their backs during his speech, largely due to Biden's administration's support for Israel.

In a surprising revelation, the New York Times reported that Kennedy had a parasitic infection removed from his brain in 2010, an assertion he confirmed in legal documents, though experts disputed the claim's accuracy. Amid ongoing debates and campaign preparations, Kennedy formally lodged a complaint with the Federal Election Commission after being excluded from the debate hosted by CNN.

Kennedy also garnered nominations from several minor parties, solidifying his position as a formidable independent candidate.

The Libertarian Party convened its national convention in Washington, D.C., featuring speeches by both Kennedy and Trump. Ultimately, former police officer Chase Oliver, an LGBTQ activist, secured the party's nomination for president after seven rounds of balloting, with Mike ter Maat as his running mate.

The U.S. Constitution Party's Randall Terry gained notoriety as the anti-abortion activist nominee for president, while Jill Stein locked in her candidacy for the Green Party.

Nicholas Hensley, national chairman of the Reform Party, elaborated on the party's unexpected nomination of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. for president. Initially focused on local races, Hensley described a pivotal video conference with Kennedy that resulted in the party's decision to forgo a convention and nominate Kennedy directly with a vote of 17 in favor, two opposed, and two abstentions.

Hensley expressed optimism about Kennedy's ability to attract votes, noting alignment on key issues like fiscal responsibility, ethics reforms, and foreign policy. Kennedy, previously a Democratic primary candidate, now runs with attorney and activist as his vice presidential pick.

Excitement and turmoil marked the Libertarian National Convention from May 23-26, where notable moments included Trump's address to the delegates amidst division over his presence. His reception was mixed, with some delegates booing, while he received applause for certain promises aligned with libertarian principles.

Following his speech, leading Libertarian candidates held a joint press conference, which was overshadowed by a candidacy frontrunner who made headlines for erratic behavior, later attributed to an unintentional cannabis high.

As the primary season ramps up, the political landscape remains dynamic, marked by unexpected alliances, legal battles, and a diverse array of candidates vying for voter support ahead of November's election.

title: New Zealand defeats South Africa to win 2024 women's T20 cricket world cup
content:
On October 20, New Zealand clinched the Women's T20 World Cup title for the first time, defeating South Africa by 32 runs in the tournament's final at the Dubai International Cricket Stadium. This tournament marked the ninth edition of the competition.

South Africa opted to field first after winning the toss. New Zealand batted and set a target of 158 runs, losing five wickets in the process. [Player name] was the standout performer with the bat, scoring 43 runs, while [Player name] contributed a valuable 38 runs. South Africa's bowling attack saw [Player name] take two wickets, making her the team's top bowler.

In response, South Africa found it challenging to meet the required run rate, finishing their innings with 126 runs for the loss of nine wickets. Captain Laura Wolvaardt led the way for South Africa with 33 runs off 27 balls, but the team fell short of the target. For New Zealand, Amelia Kerr and Rosemary Mair each took three wickets, playing a crucial role in their victory.

Amelia Kerr was recognized as both the Player of the Match and Player of the Tournament for her outstanding contributions with both bat and ball.

Reflecting on the match, South African captain Laura Wolvaardt stated, "We had a really good semi-final, and the focus was to reset, but we didn't nail our cricket today." Meanwhile, Amelia Kerr shared her excitement, saying, "I'm a little bit speechless and I'm just so stoked to get the win after all the team has been through."

title: Qantas Australian airline employees strike for better wages
content:
On Wednesday, hundreds of unionized workers from the Australian airline Qantas staged a strike, impacting operations at Melbourne and Brisbane airports as many engineers walked off the job for a full 24 hours. The workers are advocating for a 5% annual wage increase, along with a one-time payment of 15%. Qantas management has labeled this demand "unsustainable." According to the national secretary of the Australian Manufacturing Workers’ Union, workers have experienced a wage freeze for three and a half years.

In a video report from The Age, striking workers were heard chanting, "Who keeps the planes flying? We do!"

Qantas has stated that measures are in place to prevent flight delays due to the strike.

Negotiations began in April, and the current enterprise agreement expired in July.

The Qantas Engineers Alliance includes various key union representatives.

title: Grateful Dead bassist Phil Lesh dies, aged 84
content:
On Friday, musician and songwriter Phil Lesh passed away at the age of 84, surrounded by his loved ones. His family announced his death through a statement, although the cause was not disclosed.

Lesh was the former bassist and vocalist of the iconic American rock band the Grateful Dead, with whom he played for decades. He also contributed to the band's songwriting, penning notable tracks such as "Uncle John's Band," which reflects on the loss of his father. In addition to his work with the Grateful Dead, Lesh enjoyed a prolific solo career, performing with various groups made up of fellow band alumni and touring alongside his children until just months before his passing.

Born Phillip Chapman Lesh on March 15, 1940, in Berkeley, California, he began his musical journey at the age of eight with the violin and later expanded to trumpet in his high school marching band. He played in various bands and attended college while performing at nightclubs, where he met iconic guitarist Jerry Garcia. Garcia encouraged Lesh to switch to bass guitar, leading him to join the emerging lineup of the Grateful Dead, whose sound was significantly influenced by Lesh’s jazz background and musicianship. He contributed vocals and songwriting across several of the band’s songs.

Following the breakup of the Grateful Dead in 1995 after Garcia's death, Lesh continued to collaborate with former band members in various projects, including Phil Lesh & Friends, Bob Weir, and Mickey Hart. He remained an influential figure in the music scene, owning the live music venue Terrapin Crossroads from 2012 to 2021 and launching the Sunday Daydreams festival in 2023.

Phil Lesh is survived by his wife, Jill, and their two sons, Brian and Grahame.

title: Prime Minister of Canada Justin Trudeau survives a no confidence vote
content:
On Wednesday, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau successfully navigated a confidence vote in the House of Commons, which saw the motion declaring a lack of confidence in his minority Liberal government defeated by a margin of 211 to 120. The motion was introduced by the Conservative Party, the official opposition, with 119 of their MPs voting in favor. In contrast, 153 Liberal MPs opposed the measure, alongside support from most members of the other parties.

With a total of 338 members in Parliament, a simple majority was required for the motion to pass. The Conservative Party, which has gained a significant lead in recent polls ahead of the upcoming election, directed its members to back the motion. They signaled intentions to propose additional no-confidence motions, which would require backing from other parties to succeed.

This vote followed the New Democratic Party’s withdrawal from a 2022 agreement to support Trudeau's government until the next scheduled election in October 2025, a shift that has left the Prime Minister's support diminished, according to The Guardian.

The Bloc Québécois leader has indicated plans to pursue efforts to unseat the Liberal government unless their conditions are met.

Trudeau's Liberal Party has held power for nine years, but a June poll indicated that his approval rating has fallen to just 28 percent. As the election approaches, which must be called by the end of October 2025, the Conservatives continue to maintain a substantial lead in public opinion.

title: SpaceX will return stranded astronauts in February 2025, NASA announces
content:
On Saturday, NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) held a press conference announcing that two astronauts would return from the International Space Station (ISS) aboard a SpaceX spacecraft in February 2025. The forthcoming SpaceX mission, initially slated for June, will now see its spacecraft return to Earth "uncrewed," operating on autopilot with a planned landing in the New Mexico desert, possibly as soon as next month, according to NASA’s announcement.

The spacecraft, known as Starliner, encountered helium leaks and multiple thruster malfunctions during its journey to the ISS. These issues, as reported by National Public Radio (NPR), arose as Starliner approached the station. Steve Stich, manager of NASA's Commercial Crew Program, expressed uncertainty regarding the reliability of Starliner's thrusters during critical phases of flight. This particular test flight marks Boeing's first crewed space mission, following three unsuccessful attempts for such a mission.

Two NASA astronauts were launched to the ISS on June 5, with an initial expectation of an eight-day mission. A successful return is pivotal for certifying Starliner for NASA’s Commercial Crew Program. However, due to the change in plans, the astronauts will remain aboard the ISS for several additional months.

Boeing took to social media to reaffirm its commitment to safety and collaboration with NASA, emphasizing their focus on ensuring "the safety of the crew and spacecraft." They stated they are aligning their efforts with the mission requirements set by NASA and preparing for a safe uncrewed return.

In a shift of plans, NASA announced that SpaceX's Crew Dragon will now carry two astronauts instead of the planned four, making space for the return of astronauts Williams and Wilmore. SpaceX's Crew Dragon is expected to launch on September 24 for this adjusted mission, with only two crew members on board. The remaining seats will be reserved for the stranded astronauts to facilitate their return in February.

Before the upcoming launch, SpaceX’s Crew Dragon—certified for missions in 2020—will undergo modifications, including the addition of cargo, seat adjustments, and specially designed spacesuits for the two astronauts. Contingency plans are also being put in place, ensuring that the astronauts will have a flight home on the Crew-8 spacecraft if necessary.

As of now, SpaceX has successfully completed nine crewed flights to space for NASA, along with several commercial missions, as reported by the BBC.

title: Indian and Spanish leaders inaugurate India's first private military aircraft facility
content:
On October 28, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez jointly inaugurated a military aircraft facility in the Indian state of Gujarat.

This facility represents India's first private-sector Final Assembly Line (FAL) dedicated to the manufacturing of military aircraft and is a collaborative effort between Airbus and Tata Advanced Systems Limited (TASL), located on the campus of the latter.

Under the C-295 project, a total of 56 aircraft will be produced, with 16 to be assembled in Spain and delivered by 2026. The remaining 40 aircraft will be manufactured in India by the end of 2031.

In 2021, India signed a nearly INR 21,000 crore (approximately $2.5 billion) deal with Airbus to replace the aging fleet of Dornier aircraft currently in use.

This visit marks Prime Minister Sánchez's first trip to India since 2006. During his three-day visit, he plans to travel to Mumbai to engage with key industry leaders and film studios, aiming to strengthen collaboration between the Indian and Spanish entertainment sectors.

title: Russian court fines Google more money than the world's entire GDP
content:
**Russian Court Imposes Record Fine on Google for Blocking State Media**

On October 30, a leading Russian court levied an unprecedented fine of two undecillion (a two followed by 36 zeroes, or 20,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000) against American tech giant Google for blocking Russian state media channels on YouTube. This staggering amount far exceeds the entire world's GDP, which the International Monetary Fund estimates at around US$110 trillion.

Kremlin spokesperson commented on the symbolic nature of the fine, stating, "Although it is a specific amount, I cannot even say this number; it is rather filled with symbolism," as reported by the Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union, a state-run news outlet.

In addition to the fine, the court mandated that Google restore the blocked accounts within nine months, imposing a daily penalty of $1,000 (100,000 rubles) for any delays after that period.

The court's decision follows litigation initiated in 2020 by seventeen Russian television channels and other media organizations, according to NBC News.

Following the imposition of U.S. sanctions on Russia in response to its 2022 invasion of Ukraine, Google’s Russian YouTube subsidiary halted its commercial operations, significantly impacting the platform’s operations in the country.

In its quarterly earnings statement, Google referenced the ongoing legal dispute, stating, "Civil judgments that include compounding penalties have been imposed upon us in connection with disputes regarding the termination of accounts, including those of sanctioned parties." The company further expressed its belief that these legal matters would not have a material adverse effect on its earnings.

title: Kemi Badenoch becomes new leader of UK's Conservative Party
content:
On November 2, Kemi Badenoch was named the new leader of the Conservative Party in the United Kingdom, marking her as the first Black leader of a major UK political party and the fourth woman to take the helm of the Tories. 

Badenoch won the leadership contest by defeating her fellow Conservative candidate by a margin of 12,418 votes. 

She will succeed former Prime Minister Rishi Sunak in this role.

In her acceptance speech, Badenoch pledged to return the Conservatives to their "first principles."

Following the announcement, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, Labour Party leader Keir Starmer, and other political figures extended their congratulations to her on her new role as leader of the Conservative Party.

title: Lancet release yearly Countdown report raising alarm of increase in heat caused deaths
content:
**Tuesday** released the **2024 Lancet Countdown report**, highlighting urgent environmental health concerns. The report noted that the average individual experienced 50 additional days of dangerously high temperatures this year compared to **2023**. Other health determinants included extreme weather events like heatwaves, floods, and dust storms.

The report was a collaborative effort involving **122 contributors**, including advisors from **United Nations agencies** and various academic institutions. It provided a global overview, rather than focusing on a specific region such as Europe.

Key findings revealed that less than **35%** of countries are equipped to assess early symptoms of heat-related health issues, with fewer than **10%** able to address mental health concerns exacerbated by rising temperatures. The authors emphasized that this limitation restricts resources for prevention and emergency planning.

Furthermore, the report pointed out that the fossil fuel industry continues to establish new mining sites, a troubling trend that hampers the shift towards renewable energy sources.

The analysis encompassed **15 parameters**, indicating that in **2023**, the planet was already **1.45 °C** warmer than pre-industrial levels and projected to reach **2.7 °C** of warming by **2100**.

The authors urgently called for actions to reverse climate change effects and mitigate future impacts, emphasizing the need for enhancements in risk assessment and management related to health and well-being challenges.

title: World AIDS Day 2024 is marked around the world
content:
**World AIDS Day 2024: A Global Commemoration**
  
This year marks the 37th observance of World AIDS Day since its initial recognition by the United Nations in 1988. Celebrated on December 1, the day aims to raise public awareness about HIV and AIDS, with governments and non-governmental organizations worldwide making announcements in preparation for the event.

The United Nations has adopted the theme "Take the Rights Path" for 2024, which emphasizes a rights-based approach to ending AIDS. This observance is particularly significant as it is the final World AIDS Day before the target of the '95–95–95' initiative is set to be met in 2025.

In Latin America and the Caribbean, a new campaign titled "Better with Rights" was launched. In the United States, the federal government's theme focused on "Collective Action: Sustain and Accelerate HIV Progress," with President Biden hosting events at the White House for the first time. A symposium called "Enhancing the Lives of People with HIV: A Quality of Life Symposium" is scheduled for December 5. Additionally, the Biden administration has announced plans to expand the implementation of the U.S. AIDS strategy. Notably, the 35th anniversary of the AIDS Quilt will be commemorated at an event in Washington, D.C., and Latin pop star Ricky Martin will headline the World AIDS Day Concert in New York.

In South Africa, the theme "Equal Rights, Equal Care" will guide the national observance. Deputy President Paul Mashatile, who also chairs the South African National AIDS Council, will lead the commemoration in the Eastern Cape. Elsewhere on the continent, the World AIDS Day 2024 Half Marathon in Kenya, focused on raising awareness for men and boys living with HIV, was hosted by Health Secretary Susan Nakhumicha. Meanwhile, in Nigeria, efforts are directed towards ending AIDS among children by 2030. Activists in the country have been advocating for necessary government funding for the National HIV/AIDS Fund, originally intended to be established in 2016.

In Europe, the World Health Organization (WHO) agency is commemorating the day by releasing the latest HIV surveillance data for the European region. In the UK, Prime Minister Keir Starmer has committed to eliminating all new HIV transmissions in England by 2030, alongside new funding initiatives for domestic opt-out testing and expanded international health services. In Central and Eastern Europe, countries outside the EU, such as Bosnia and Herzegovina, have largely organized informational events, counseling, and free testing in major cities.

Global Response:

- **Americas:** Launch of awareness campaigns and events at the White House.
- **Africa:** Focus on equity in care and awareness-targeted events.
- **Europe:** New funding initiatives and surveillance data release.
- **Asia:** Ongoing advocacy for HIV funding and healthcare equity.

The global community continues to unite in the fight against HIV/AIDS, reminding us all of the critical importance of rights, resources, and collective action in the journey toward ending the epidemic.

title: Smithsonian National Zoo euthanizes elderly Asian elephant
content:
Kamala, an Asian elephant at the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington, D.C., was euthanized on November 2 due to an irreversible decline in her health caused by osteoarthritis. She was approximately 50 years old. 

Kamala’s posture had made her susceptible to this degenerative joint and bone condition, which the elephant care team managed through a regimen of multi-modal therapies, including monthly injections. In recent weeks, her mobility had significantly decreased, and she often remained in one place, likely due to discomfort. Given her poor prognosis, the animal care staff made the difficult decision to end her suffering.

Born in the wild around 1975 in Sri Lanka, Kamala was raised at a sanctuary for orphaned elephants before being relocated to the zoo in 1976. She had two calves during her time in Calgary: a male named Calvin, born in June 1986, and a female named Maharani, born in 1990. In May 2014, she was transferred to the Smithsonian National Zoo along with her calf Maharani and another herd mate.

The International Union for Conservation of Nature categorizes Asian elephants as endangered. Kamala's lineage has played a vital role in the birth of at least a dozen elephant calves worldwide, and the zoo noted she was a significant ambassador for her species.

Though her herd mates were not present during the procedure, they were allowed time to be with her afterward.

title: United States President-elect and Canadian Prime Minister have dinner in Palm Beach, Florida
content:
On November 29, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau traveled to Florida for a private dinner with United States President-elect Donald Trump. The discussion centered around Trump’s threats to impose significant tariffs on Canadian goods.

This meeting followed a phone conversation between Trump and Trudeau on November 2, where they discussed Trump’s proposal for a 25% tariff on all goods imported from Mexico and Canada. Trudeau had previously criticized the plan, warning that it would negatively impact "Canadians who work so well with the United States,” while also increasing costs for American consumers and harming U.S. industries. Trump argued that the tariff would remain in place until there was a substantial reduction in "drugs, particularly fentanyl, and all illegal immigration impacting our country."

Trudeau arrived at the venue ahead of the dinner, which also included North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum, who is a nominee for Secretary of the Interior; businessman Wilbur Ross, a nominee for Secretary of Commerce; and Pennsylvania Senator-elect John Fetterman.

Following the meeting, Trudeau described their discussion as an "excellent conversation." He shared a photo of the dinner on X (formerly Twitter), expressing optimism about collaborative opportunities in the future.

Trump also took to social media to characterize the meeting as "very productive," highlighting that they discussed several important issues requiring cooperation between the two countries, including the opioid crisis that has devastated many lives, the need for fair trade agreements that protect American workers, and the substantial trade deficit the U.S. has with Canada.

title: Court ruling upholds TikTok ban unless ByteDance sells stake
content:
On Friday, a federal court upheld a ban on TikTok, contingent on its China-based parent company selling its stake in the platform.

U.S. national security officials and policymakers have raised concerns about TikTok, citing the potential for the Chinese government to exploit the app to compromise the privacy of American users and manipulate its algorithm to influence public opinion in the United States.

China has been reticent to allow the forced sale of TikTok.

In response, TikTok spokesperson Michael Hughes announced that the company plans to appeal the decision and is optimistic it will be overturned. Hughes criticized the ruling as being based on "inaccurate, flawed, and hypothetical information," and expressed concern that it could silence the voices of over 170 million Americans who use the app.

The unanimous ruling by a panel of three judges rejected arguments claiming that the ban violated the rights of American users and stated that it is in compliance with national security laws. The court emphasized that, given TikTok's "expansive reach," such a ban is necessary to safeguard national security.

The ruling received praise from various lawmakers.

President-elect has indicated a desire to find a way to preserve the app, despite having previously supported the ban.

title: Manslaughter charges against Daniel Penny dismissed following jury deadlock
content:
On Friday, Judge Maxwell Wiley dismissed a manslaughter charge against former subway passenger Daniel Penny in connection with the death of Jordan Neely, an event that took place in a Manhattan subway station on May 1, 2023. The jury will now deliberate on a lesser charge of criminally negligent homicide, following the prosecution's request due to the jury's inability to reach a unanimous verdict on the original charge.

According to reports, Judge Wiley instructed the jurors to return home after they informed him they were deadlocked. The maximum penalty for criminally negligent homicide in New York is four years in prison, significantly less than the fifteen years Penny could have faced had he been convicted of manslaughter.

Neely died during an altercation with Penny, who has maintained that he acted in self-defense. Penny's defense team argued that Neely was threatening other passengers on the train, while the prosecution contended that Penny used excessive force in subduing Neely and held him in a chokehold for an extended period.

title: Suspect in shooting death of UnitedHealthcare CEO fled New York City by bus, police say
content:
On Friday, Commissioner Jessica Tisch informed the media that authorities now believe the suspect accused of shooting CEO Thompson has left the area. It is believed he fled on a bus shortly after the crime.

Police have also recovered an abandoned backpack at the scene, which is thought to belong to the shooter.

During the attack, the suspect concealed his face with a mask, only briefly revealing it during his time in the city. Photos released by police appear to show the suspect unmasked in a public location. As of the latest update, police have not identified the shooter or established a motive for the attack.

The unidentified assailant ambushed Thompson from behind early Wednesday outside the venue where he was scheduled to participate in UnitedHealthcare's annual event. Security footage captured the shooter fleeing on a bicycle before taking a taxi to a nearby bus terminal, though he was not seen exiting. This terminal provides access to various destinations, including nearby cities and regions.

title: Harvey Weinstein hospitalized in Manhattan after "alarming" blood test results
content:
On Monday, former film producer Harvey Weinstein was hospitalized at [hospital name] following test results that his lawyers labeled as "alarming." Imran Ansari, his attorney, stated that the 72-year-old will remain in the hospital "until his condition stabilizes."

Ansari also alleged that jail staff at [jail name] in New York have provided inadequate medical care to Weinstein, who is currently incarcerated while awaiting a retrial on sexual assault charges, which he denies.

Weinstein has previously been diagnosed with [specific medical conditions].

title: Israel-Lebanon ceasefire faces several violations
content:
On Monday, December 2, Israel conducted its most extensive airstrikes on Lebanon since a ceasefire was established, resulting in the deaths of 11 civilians. These strikes were launched in response to projectiles fired at Israeli forces by Hezbollah—the first such attack from Hezbollah since the ceasefire went into effect. Hezbollah contended that Israel had itself violated the ceasefire agreement, asserting that their actions were a warning due to these alleged violations. Israel, in turn, accused Hezbollah of breaching the ceasefire on multiple unspecified occasions.

As of December 6, 2024, both parties have repeatedly exchanged accusations regarding ceasefire violations, with Israeli strikes continuing in the region.

Since its inception on November 28, 2024, the ceasefire has reportedly been breached several times. The ceasefire arrangement was initially proposed by Amos Hochstein, a senior official in the Biden administration. On Sunday, November 25, it was announced that Israel was considering the proposal. European Union foreign policy chief Josep Borrell stated that the proposal was awaiting final approval from Israel, emphasizing the need to apply pressure on both the Israeli government and Hezbollah to accept the ceasefire.

The following day, Israel and Hezbollah reached an agreement, which went into effect shortly thereafter. However, on November 28, Israel launched airstrikes in Lebanon, claiming that they were a reaction to Hezbollah's alleged activities at a rocket storage facility in southern Lebanon that were thought to violate the ceasefire.

On the same day, the Lebanese Army accused Israel of violating the ceasefire by conducting strikes using "various weapons" and maintaining surveillance over Lebanese airspace with warplanes and drones. Israeli officials have stated that their troops will be withdrawn gradually while ensuring the enforcement of the ceasefire, reiterating warnings to civilians not to return to areas with an Israeli military presence. They also asserted their right to respond with force against Hezbollah should the ceasefire terms be breached.

title: Trump wins 2024 U.S. Presidential Election, securing 312 electoral votes and all swing states
content:
**Trump Secures Victory in 2024 U.S. Presidential Election**

Donald Trump won the 2024 U.S. presidential election on November 6, surpassing the required 270 Electoral College votes. Following the post-election ballot count on Saturday, Trump secured a total of 312 electoral votes by winning all the key battleground states, while Kamala Harris received 226 votes. Trump is poised to be inaugurated as the 47th president of the United States on January 20, 2025.

Trump's victory was clinched after he successfully flipped Wisconsin, allowing him to exceed the 270-vote threshold needed to secure the presidency in the Electoral College system, which comprises 538 votes across all states and Washington, D.C. His win was bolstered by significant victories in other crucial swing states, including Michigan, Pennsylvania, Georgia, North Carolina, and Nevada, all of which played vital roles in his electoral lead.

In the nationwide popular vote, Trump garnered approximately 50.5%, translating to around 74 million votes, compared to Harris's 48.0%. Additionally, the Republican Party retained control of the House of Representatives, although results remain pending in various districts where a total of 218 seats is needed for a majority.

In his victory speech, Trump expressed his gratitude to the American people, stating, "I want to thank you for the extraordinary honor of being elected your 47th president and your 45th president." He acknowledged the dedication of his supporters, remarking, "We've been through so much together, and today you showed up in record numbers to deliver a victory."

In her concession speech, Harris accepted the election results and pledged a peaceful transfer of power, vowing to continue her advocacy on the issues she has championed.

In addition to the presidential contest, U.S. voters elected new members of Congress, with elections held for 34 out of 100 Senate seats and all 435 seats in the House of Representatives. Furthermore, voters in eleven states chose new governors, and elections for state legislatures took place in 44 states.

title: Impeachment of South Korean president Yoon Suk Yeol fails
content:
On Saturday, motions to impeach South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol failed as most members of his ruling party, the People Power Party, opted not to participate in the session to consider the impeachment trial.

The vote followed an unexpected move by President Yoon that left many citizens startled. Despite support for impeachment from some within his own party, including the party leader, there were questions raised about his fitness for office, with calls for his resignation emerging from various factions.

In a televised address, President Yoon expressed his regret to constituents for the unrest he has caused across the nation. 

Speculation has arisen that Yoon's decision to declare martial law was influenced by recent political challenges, including a scandal from last month concerning allegations of misuse of power related to the People Power Party, which he has denied. He has previously faced criticism from former political opponents for perceived misjudgments.

Yoon's declaration of martial law on Tuesday was met with immediate backlash from lawmakers. Although South Korean law permits the president to impose martial law under exceptional circumstances, it also empowers the National Assembly to overturn such a decision with a majority vote. In this instance, the assembly voted overwhelmingly against the president, with a result of 190-0.

In light of the failed impeachment efforts, political unrest and widespread protests are anticipated across the country. Throughout its history, South Korea has experienced several declarations of martial law.

title: President of South Korea declares and lifts martial law
content:
Late Tuesday night, President Yoon of South Korea made an unexpected television address at 11 PM local time (14:00 UTC), during which he announced the imposition of martial law in response to rising local unrest attributed to "anti-state forces." This decision granted the military authority to oversee the country's security. The martial law was officially lifted at 4:30 AM Wednesday (19:30 UTC on December 3). The National Assembly responded by filing an impeachment motion on Thursday morning, which must be voted on within 72 hours.

In his speech, President Yoon explained that the measure was taken due to the Assembly's initiation of “22 motions to impeach government officials” and the push for the impeachment of a tenth official. He emphasized the necessity to protect the Republic of Korea from North Korean communist threats and eradicate pro-Pyongyang forces that undermine the freedoms and well-being of the South Korean people. CNN reported that his decree effectively banned all political activities.

Lawmakers confronted soldiers outside the National Assembly building during the unrest. At approximately 1:00 AM local time (16:00 UTC on December 3), the Assembly convened and unanimously passed a resolution to lift martial law with a vote of 190–0.

Following this, at 4:30 AM (19:30 UTC on December 3), President Yoon announced that martial law would be lifted as soon as the cabinet could establish a quorum. He urged the National Assembly to halt what he described as reckless actions that could paralyze the functions of the state through repeated impeachment and legislative manipulation. Shortly thereafter, the cabinet voted to officially lift martial law.

The leader of the conservative party to which President Yoon belongs criticized the declaration as “wrong” and stated his intention to join the opposition in opposing it, as reported by CNN.

On Thursday morning, President Yoon appointed Choi Byung-hyuk as the new military minister, replacing his predecessor who was reportedly involved in recommending the declaration of martial law, according to SBS News.

title: World leaders attend grand reopening of Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris five years after damaging fire
content:
On Saturday, the historic cathedral reopened its doors after five years of closure due to extensive damage caused by a devastating fire that compromised the building's structure.

Approximately 50 world leaders gathered for the grand reopening event, which spanned the weekend and celebrated the significance of the cathedral's art, culture, and historical heritage. French President [Name] described the occasion as a symbol of national pride, stating, "This cathedral is a joyful metaphor for what our nation embodies and what the world should aspire to be. It stands reborn, reminding us of the lessons of fragility, humility, and resilience. Tonight, we share in the joy and pride of this moment."

Originally planned as an outdoor ceremony, the event was relocated indoors due to inclement weather.

The cathedral, completed in 1345, underwent extensive restoration work following the fire, involving the efforts of 1,200 skilled artisans. The cathedral is set to hold its first mass on Sunday, marking a significant milestone in its recovery.

title: Ruby slippers worn by American actress Judy Garland in 1939 film The Wizard of Oz break sales record, sold for US$28 million at auction
content:
On Saturday, a pair of ruby slippers worn by American actress Judy Garland while portraying Dorothy in the 1939 classic film "The Wizard of Oz" was sold at Heritage Auctions in the US for an astonishing $28 million to an anonymous buyer. Experts believe that the shoes' rich history and provenance significantly contributed to their record-setting price.

The final sale price of the slippers surpassed initial estimates by a staggering $25 million. With auction fees added, the total cost for the buyer comes to $32.5 million, establishing a new record for the highest price ever paid for an entertainment memorabilia item. This record eclipses the previous high of $5.52 million for the iconic blue dress worn by Dorothy in the same film.

According to CBS News, over 800 people participated in the bidding for the shoes. Only four pairs of ruby slippers from the film are known to have survived to the present day, making this particular pair exceptionally rare.

In addition to their significance as part of an iconic costume, this pair of slippers garnered attention in 2005 when they were stolen while on display at the Judy Garland Museum in Grand Rapids, Minnesota. They remained missing for thirteen years until they were recovered by authorities in 2018. The Judy Garland Museum was among the bidders at the auction, seeking to reclaim the cherished piece, which had initially been loaned to them by memorabilia collector Michael Shaw.

The shoes have been referred to as the "Holy Grail of Hollywood memorabilia" and "the most iconic piece of film history" by the auctioneers.

"The Wizard of Oz" has recently enjoyed renewed public interest following the release of a film centered on the original movie's antagonist, the Wicked Witch of the West. Among other memorabilia from the original film, a hat worn by Margaret Hamilton while portraying the witch was also auctioned off.

title: Indian chess grandmaster Gukesh Dommaraju, 18, becomes youngest world chess champion of all time
content:
On Thursday, an 18-year-old teenager from India, Arjun Kalyan Dommaraju, triumphed over China's reigning champion, Ding Liren, in a thrilling match held at the World Chess Championship. Dommaraju's victory makes him the youngest world chess champion in history.

The match was described by commentators as "tight" and seemingly "on the verge of a tie." Despite both players displaying what was characterized as "near-perfect accuracy," Dommaraju secured his win due to a critical blunder by Liren late in the game. Liren mistakenly attempted to capture one of Dommaraju's pieces at the cost of sacrificing one of his own. In a post-game press conference, a clearly shaken Liren admitted he was "totally in shock" after the realization hit him.

The title was previously held by Russian grandmaster Anatoly Karpov, who became the youngest world chess champion in 1985 at the age of 22. Dommaraju, now the new titleholder, achieved this monumental feat at just 18 years old. NPR hailed Dommaraju as a "chess prodigy."

title: Actress Selena Gomez announces engagement to record producer Benny Blanco
content:
On Wednesday, American actress and musician Selena Gomez announced her engagement to record producer Drew Taggart. She shared a picture of her engagement ring on her Instagram account, prompting congratulations from other celebrities.

According to The Hollywood Reporter, Gomez and Taggart began dating in June 2023 and made their relationship public in December of the same year. In November, Gomez expressed her feelings to the publication, saying, “This is the safest I've ever felt in one relationship, and I see a future with this person.”

The couple previously collaborated on the song "I Can't Get Enough," which was released in 2019, and Gomez's 2023 single "Single Soon."

With 423 million followers, Gomez is currently the most-followed woman on Instagram, as reported by the BBC.

title: Princess Yuriko of Mikasa, Japan's oldest royal family member, dies at 101
content:
Japan mourns the passing of Princess Yuriko, who died on November 14 at 9:32 PM UTC (November 15 at 6:32 AM JST) in the central Chūō ward of Tokyo. The Princess was 101 years old, making her the last member of the Imperial family born in the 1910s and the oldest since the late 19th century.

Princess Yuriko's health began to decline on November 7, following reports of diminishing overall bodily functions, including issues with her heart and kidneys. Her granddaughter, Princess Akiko, returned from the UK to visit her, along with other family members, including Yasuko and her husband. All were present except for Yasuko and her spouse at the time of Yuriko's passing. The Imperial Household Agency stated that her cause of death was due to old age.

Emperor Emeritus Akihito and Empress Emerita Michiko expressed their condolences on November 15. A funeral is scheduled for November 26, with Princess Akiko serving as the chief mourner. The Imperial Household Agency also announced via Instagram that a condolences book will be available for the public to sign at the Mikasa estate.

title: FBI Director Christopher Wray to resign
content:
On December 11, FBI Director Christopher Wray announced his resignation during an internal meeting, stating that he would step down before President-elect Donald Trump takes office in January. Wray's decision follows Trump's previous statements indicating his intention to fire Wray upon his inauguration. According to Reuters, Trump's move appears aimed at diminishing the FBI's authority, linking it to the earlier investigation into Trump that took place after he left office in 2020.

Wray explained that his resignation comes after thoughtful consideration. He plans to continue serving in his role until the end of the current administration in January. "In my view, this is the best way to prevent the bureau from becoming further embroiled in controversy while upholding the values and principles that guide our work," Wray stated.

Trump responded to Wray's resignation, calling it "a great day for America."

On November 30, Trump announced the nomination of his former aide to lead the FBI, a change that will take effect when he officially assumes office.

During his first term in 2017, Trump nominated Wray as the replacement for former FBI Director James Comey, whom he dismissed after Comey became unpopular due to his investigation into alleged ties between Trump's 2016 campaign and Russia.

title: South Korean president impeached by nation's parliament
content:
On Saturday, the South Korean National Assembly, composed of 300 members, voted 204 to 85 to impeach President Yoon Suk-yeol. 

This vote followed Yoon’s controversial declaration and subsequent lifting of martial law, which he asserted was necessary to protect democracy amid months of political turmoil. His actions drew significant criticism, leading to calls for his impeachment.

The impeachment motion came after a failed attempt the previous week, where members of Yoon's ruling People Power Party staged a walkout during the hearing. In this recent vote, the party permitted its members to decide individually, resulting in 12 votes in favor of impeachment and 85 against it.

As a consequence of the impeachment, Yoon was suspended from his position, and Prime Minister Han Duck-soo has been appointed as the acting president. Han has expressed his intention to restore “normalcy” to the nation.

Both Han and Finance Minister Choo Kyung-ho have been involved in a police investigation related to Yoon. Notably, Yoon is now the first South Korean president to be barred from leaving the country, which stems from an investigation into allegations surrounding his administration. Opposition leader Lee Jae-myung praised the impeachment, stating, "The people are the owners of this country."

Yoon characterized the impeachment as a minor setback, pledging to "never give up." He stated, "I will take your criticism, praise, and support to heart and will do my utmost for the country until the end." The impeachment decision awaits ratification by the Constitutional Court, which has 180 days to reach a verdict. Should the court choose to uphold the impeachment, a new presidential election will be required within 60 days.

Acting Chief Justice of the Constitutional Court reiterated that the trial would be conducted in a "speedy and fair" manner.

The motion’s approval sparked celebrations outside the National Assembly, where thousands of demonstrators, braving the cold, sang and cheered. Many were seen waving banners often associated with protests. Polls suggest that approximately 75% of South Koreans support Yoon's removal from office.

Yoon, prior to his presidency, oversaw the prosecution that led to the impeachment of former President Park Geun-hye in 2016.

title: Luigi Mangione, suspect in killing of US healthcare CEO, charged with terrorism
content:
On Tuesday, the District Attorney announced that 26-year-old Luigi Mangione has been charged in connection with the murder of CEO Thompson in Manhattan, New York, on December 4. District Attorney Alvin Bragg stated that Mangione allegedly carried out the attack with the intent to "sow terror."

Under a New York State law, prosecutors can pursue terrorism charges if the defendant is found to have intended to intimidate or coerce a civilian population, influence government policies through intimidation or coercion, or impact government conduct through murder, assassination, or kidnapping.

Mangione's attorney did not address the terrorism charges but claimed he had not yet seen evidence linking Mangione's weapon to Thompson's death. In addition to the murder charge, Mangione faces two more counts.

Currently, Mangione is being held in custody in Pennsylvania without bail and faces a potential life sentence without parole for the murder charge.

A court hearing is scheduled for December 19 to determine whether Mangione will be extradited to New York for the murder charges. This date coincides with Mangione's preliminary hearing for gun charges in Pennsylvania.

Mangione was apprehended on December 9 in Pennsylvania after an employee recognized him at a local business and reported his presence. When approached by police, Mangione reportedly became "visibly nervous" and started shaking when asked if he had been in New York recently, according to CBS News. He has been charged with "carrying a gun without a license,” forgery, providing false identification to authorities, and possessing instruments of crime, as reported by Australia's ABC News.

Authorities found Mangione in possession of a firearm and a silencer believed to be used in Thompson's murder, along with fake identification that matched those he used while staying at a Manhattan hostel, as reported by CBS News. Additionally, he was carrying a substantial amount of cash, including foreign currency, according to BBC News Online.

Authorities also noted that he had a handwritten note discussing health insurance companies allegedly prioritizing profits over customer care. CBS News reported that the NYPD has clarified Mangione was never a UnitedHealthcare client, suggesting that he may have targeted Thompson due to the company's significant size and influence.

New York Police Commissioner Keechant Sewell emphasized the severity of the situation, stating, "Any attempt to rationalize this is vile, reckless, and offensive to our deeply held principles of justice."

Originally from Maryland, Mangione's case drew further attention when NYPD Chief of Detectives Joseph Kenny revealed that Mangione's mother had reported him missing on November 18 and had expressed to authorities that the murder "might be something that she could see him doing."

title: International Criminal Court issues arrest warrants for Netanyahu, Gallant, and Deif over alleged war crimes in Israel-Hamas war
content:
On November 21, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issued arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, and senior Hamas military leader Mohammed Deif. The warrants allege that the three were involved in war crimes during the 2023-2024 conflict.

Netanyahu's office dismissed the ICC's decision, labeling it a politically motivated act. In contrast, Hamas expressed support for the ICC's actions. The reaction from various countries and organizations has been mixed, reflecting a range of opinions on the situation.

According to the European Union, the ICC's decision is binding for all its member states. While non-member states like the U.S. do not recognize the court's authority, several signatory countries, including various EU nations, have indicated their commitment to comply with ICC regulations. As a result of the court's ruling, Netanyahu and others now face the risk of international arrest warrants, which could complicate their foreign travel.

The ICC's Pre-Trial Chamber has charged Netanyahu and Gallant with war crimes that include the starvation of civilians as a tactic of warfare, persecution, and systematic attacks on civilian populations. Deif, accused of orchestrating targeted rocket attacks and the intentional murder of civilians, has reportedly been killed by Israeli forces. While Hamas has not confirmed or denied his death, the ICC stated it is still in the process of verifying the information. Prior to this, the court had dropped charges against seven individuals due to their deaths.

The arrest warrants require the 124 ICC member states to detain the accused if they enter their territories. Since the ICC does not have its own enforcement capabilities, it depends on member states to implement these warrants. Previous instances have shown that such warrants can significantly restrict the international movements of indicted individuals as member states are obligated to uphold these legal commands within their jurisdictions.
